passages.text: Firing on all AI Optics Cylinders; Initiated with a Buy&hd TP of $165

We initiate coverage on Lumentum (LITE) with a Buy and a $165 price target. Despite LITE being up 50%+ YTD, we continue to see further upside in the stock and prefer LITE to COHR over the next 12-months as we expect LITE to be more agnostic to the AI optics technology changes and module share dynamics. We see LITE being well on track to outpace both company and Street's longer-term expectations with the ramp of its industry leading EML and its new AI products in emerging markets such as OCS and CPO. We subsequently model a +8%/+10% sales and EPS upside in FY2027E (Jun-2027) and value LITE at $165 or 23x P/E applied to our FY2027E earnings power of $7. Our 23x P/E multiple is at a 21% premium to the 19x average P/E of AI optics peers which we view as justified on an earnings growth adjusted basis.

**EML ramp is well on track** — We consider LITE a primary beneficiary of the AI accelerators ramp as it provides the key Electro-absorption Modulated Laser (EML) used in most AI transceivers. We expect LITE to be the key provider to ~50% of EML-based transceivers 800G and 1.6T transceivers. While questions around capacity remain a risk, we came out of our chat with LITE CEO and CFO last week reassured by the company's strategic capacity planning.

**Preferred US AI optics name** — Over the next 12-months we prefer LITE to COHR amid its 1) higher growth perspective (42% sales growth in FY2026 vs. 9% and 29% 3-year CAGR vs. 12%) driven notably by the increased migration to EML and LITE's expansion of its transceivers and Optical Circuit Switch (OCS) customer base. 2) Faster margin expansion (we estimate 850bps non-GAAP gross margin growth between FY2025 to FY2028). See page 19 for details. 3) Overall, more agnostic AI optics portfolio as LITE is a key supplier of components across pluggable, OCS and Co-Packaged Optics (CPO) technologies.

**ECOC and OCP conferences are the next catalysts** — We expect the ECOC (Sept-29 to Oct-1) and OCP conference (Oct-13 to Oct-16) to be the next catalysts for the stock. We see LITE's 200G EML technology's adoption as a key topic at ECOC and believe the OCP's recently announced Optical Circuit Switching (OCS) project led by Lumentum will further shed light on OCS being a viable AI spine switch option vs. packet switches.

We see LITE as not only an AI story ( \(40\% +\) sales exposure) but as also a company with a strong margin expansion story (860/1450bps non- GAAP gross- margin and operating margin growths between FY2025 and FY2028E). As the need for faster and more reliable optical connection increases with AI, we think LITE's \(20+\) years Indium Phosphide (InP) technology leadership should continue to bear fruit via innovation both on the laser front but increasingly on the module front. With that in mind, we model sales growing at a \(29\%\) CAGR over the next 3 fiscal years. With these growth assumptions we see \(+8\% +10\%\) sales and EPS upside in FY2027E (Jun- 2027) and value LITE at \(\) 165\(or\) 23\times P/E\(applied to our FY2027E earnings power of\) \sim \(\) 7. Our 23x P/E multiple is at a 21% premium to 19x average P/E of AI optics peers. We model LITE to grow EPS at 58% CAGR in next three fiscal years vs. \(40\%\) AI optics peers. Therefore, on an earnings growth adjusted basis, we consider a higher P/E multiple is justified.

1) Direct beneficiary of the AI units' ramp: We expect LITE to continue benefiting from the ongoing pivot to single mode InP-based lasers. We estimate LITE will likely continue to be a share leader in AI EML lasers at \(\sim 50\%\) of shares as it is, a key supplier to transceiver leaders such as Innolight and Coherent. We are modeling LITE's AI EML sales to reach \(\sim\) 700M+ in FY2026E. We base our FY2026E AI sales estimates on a bottom up model with the following key assumptions:

- We expect AI accelerators to grow at a \(22\%\) CAGR between C2025E and C2028E. We see merchant units to grow at a \(16\%\) CAGR during that period driven mostly by NVDA, which we suspect will continue to capture the bulk of AI accelerators investment due to its technology leadership and large installed base. Coming from a smaller base, we expect ASIC units to grow at a CAGR of \(32\%\) as various ASIC programs come online particularly in the 2026-2027 timeframe. See note.
- \(\sim 2x\) AI transceivers to AI accelerator average ratio.
- We are assuming \(\sim 50\%\) LITE AI EML unit market share and LSD% share of AI transceivers in FY2026E.
- We assume weighted ASPs to sit between \(\) 10\(and\) \ \(15\) for EML lasers and \(\) 400+\(for AI transceivers.

2) Expanding AI portfolio will drive the path to \(\) 750M\(quarterly revenue: We expect Lumentum to benefit from the AI ramp in various areas including OCS and CPO.

Optical Circuit Switch (OCS) will drive the path to \(\) 750M\$ ... The OCS market can be divided into two pieces 1) higher port count 2) lower port count. Lumentum previously highlighted leading on the higher port count front where 2 out of their 3 wins are in. In terms of future opportunities, 5/7 of the company's opportunities are also higher port count. The primary benefits Lumentum has vs competition in higher port count are at a power level, ultra- wideband level (MEMS unlike liquid crystal- based operates seamlessly across the O, C and L optical bands), as well stability and reliability levels. One of the two wins Lumentum has in OCS is with a customer (we think GOOGL) that has an in- house option. However, Lumentum's view is that its OCS switch is cheaper and better performing vs that customer's in- house solution. With that, the company expects to take significant share vs the in- house solution. Additionally, LITE indicates that it is unlikely that this customer will continue with the in- house option. LITE also benefits from the rapidity of its manufacturing when it comes to OCS which would be crucial as the technology ramps. This combined with their technological advantage at higher port count likely drove a second hyperscalers (likely AMZN) to use them as sole source. The third win is at a lower port count \(64 \times 64\). This area is more competitive with companies such as COHR having a viable alternative, but LITE discussed being able to also win in that area due to its lower return loss (or high pass through which reflects how easily light can go by without being reflected). Similar to LITE's management, we estimate that when it comes to greenfield opportunities in AI data centers (particularly for large training clusters), OCS should be a viable alternative to packet switches as the OCS switches provide cost, power saving and improved latency. Additionally, OCS switches are data- rate agnostic, allowing them to support 400G, 800G and soon 1.6T without the need for upgrade. We expect LITE's OCS sales to be \(\) 100M+\(quarterly by FY2028E as the company builds on its three key customers.

CPO Opportunity: We expect Lumentum to be a primary beneficiary of the CPO trends starting with Nvidia. At a transceiver level, LITE is not a direct supplier to Nvidia specifically, rather it benefits from its customers (Innolight, Coherent among others) ultimately selling transceivers to Nvidia. Now with this CPO opportunity, the company can sell directly its Ultra- High- Power (UHP) laser into Nvidia systems. Though selling eight (8) EML chips into a transceiver customer roughly equals in content to selling one UHP laser. That said, unlike at a transceiver level where LITE detains \(\sim 50\%\) of the shares of EML based transceivers, with
Nvidia's CPO the company is either sole or primary source. This makes the potential content lost by the displacement of transceivers by CPO switches more than offset by LITE's UHP laser content.
Figure 7. Lumentum Photonics Roadmap for AI Scaling

As the acceleration of network and compute fabric bandwidth demand persist, innovations in both system and chip architectures are required to mitigate the slowing of Moore's law. In parallel, copper interconnects are fast reaching their bandwidth- distance limits with 224 SerDes technology being prevalent sooner than expected as NVIDIA's upcoming launches position 1.6T switches Quantum on the InfiniBand front and Spectrum- X on the Ethernet front. We think 2026 will truly see the emergence of 224 SerDes. This was echoed by Marvell at CES with the need to go active and/or optical with the advent of 224 SerDes. Solutions that are being discussed are Silicon photonics (SiPho) and Co- Packaged Optics (CPO) for artificial intelligence/machine learning (AI/ML) and high- performance computing (HPC) applications.

What is SiPho? SiPho is a cutting- edge technology that integrates optical functions, such as the generation, manipulation, and detection of light, directly onto silicon- based semiconductor platform. It leverages the unique properties of photon particles of light to transmit and process information. Because it is a technology build on the widely used silicon material, its future integration with electronic components is also built on silicon. This compatibility not only simplifies production but also makes SiPho solutions often more cost- effective ones. Another advantage of SiPho is that it has the potential for higher data transmission rates and can typically travel further distance with less signal loss compared to the traditional electronic signals. SiPho can be used in a pluggable form or in a system form (switch or XPUs) via what is called optical engines. In terms of components a SiPho chip often has the following components:

- The laser's primary role is to be the source of light as silicon as a material does not inherently emit light. Some SiPho is built in the light source into the chip/engine, however that is fairly uncommon. Typically, an external light

source (ELS) is plugged into the optical engine containing the SiPho. Unlike traditional optical modules, silicon photonics uses common wavelength (CW) lasers, which are less expensive and easier to make. "CW is like a lightbulb...It just shines a constant light. It is easier to make and is available from multiple sources and it's inexpensive," according to Dr Loi Nguyen, Executive VP of Marvell's Optical group.

- An optical modulator is a device which can be used for manipulating the properties of light. Its primary role in a SiPho engine is to convert electrical bits to optical bits.- Similarly, a detector also can manipulate the properties of light and in a SiPho engine it focuses on converting the optical bits to electrical bits before it is sent out.- The filter primary role is to mux and demux the optical data. "Muxing" refers to the process of combining multiple optical signals of different wavelengths onto a single fiber, while "demuxing" is the opposite process of separating those combined signals back into individual channels, essentially allowing for the transmission of multiple data streams over a single fiber optic cable.- Fiber couplers are devices sitting at the edge of a given SiPho engine module to facilitate the movement of the optical bits from the SiPho chip to the cable.- Depending on the SiPho chip a driver to amplify the electrical signals from the DSP in case of a transceiver and a transimpedance amplifier (TIA) to amplify the electrical signal from the detector can be used.

What is CPO? Co- Packaged Optics (CPO) is an advanced heterogeneous integration of optics and silicon on a single packaged substrate aimed at addressing next generation bandwidth and power challenges. CPO combines a wide range of expertise in fiber optics, digital signal processing (DSP), switch ASICs, and state- of- the- art packaging & test to provide disruptive system value for the data center and cloud infrastructure.

What are the benefits? Broadcom claims that CPO can 1) reduce power consumption by \(30\% +\) vs. existing solutions, 2) it can reduce \(40\%\) optics \(\) /bit\(and 3) can enable 1 Tbps/mm Bandwidth density which for context is\) 40\% +\(above the most advanced optical transceivers form - factors. See our detailed CPO note for more detailed.

Recall, Nvidia is entering the CPO era with its Quantum- X Photonics InfiniBand switches (2H2025) and NVIDIA Spectrum- X Photonics Ethernet switches coming in 2H2026. The upcoming Quantum- X InfiniBand ASIC with CPO has 2 switch ASIC chips, with each coupled with six distinct CPO engines (modules), and each with three connectors, making the total number of plugs (800Gb/s) 18 with a total of 36 ports (each plug seems to have two ports). 18 ELS (External Laser Source) will be used as light source, with each having 6 CW lasers. Next to the ELS laser is an

optical transceiver plugged into the NIC for management. NVDA, when asked about the risk of failure with the use of CPO on the switch directly, mentioned that the healthiness of the CPO switch is in- line with traditional switch, as NVDA was able to sidestep it using innovative packaging and pluggable lasers. NVDA pointed to \(3.5x\) power saving using CPO (Spectrum version) vs. transceivers, partially due to \(4x\) fewer lasers. CPO also offers \(63x\) greater signal integrity, \(10x\) better network resiliency, and \(1.3x\) faster deployment than traditional solutions, according to the company.
Figure 10. Quantum-X CPO

DCI demand...is booming with practically signals moving further to the green side every week management pointed out. LITE is benefiting from the boom via its narrow line lasers which is a subcomponent of coherent modules. For narrow line lasers and subassemblies products for DCI product the company is also sold out until C2026. Although LITE represents around 1/3 of the telecom business, with a FY2025- FY2028 CAGR of \(26\%\) we expect the DCI portion of the telecom segment to represent \(45\%\) of the telecom segment by FY2028.

We estimate that the AI networking opportunity is expanding beyond the server connection within a data center to AI platforms connecting multiple data centers through DCI. Unlike the general understanding that DCI is primarily an inference story, we believe that training will be an increasingly larger opportunity for DCI through the concept called multi data center training. In fact, as AI clusters sizes are set to reach up to \(300K+\) GPUs as soon as 2025, containing models in one data center unit will likely not be sustainable long term, amid constraints related to power, regulations among others. With that, hyperscalers are adopting and plan to further expand the adoption of the multi data center training approach. Google trained Gemini 1 Ultra using that framework while other key AI players such as Open AI, Microsoft, and Anthropic are working to expand their current training platforms to various data centers as well. In fact, we believe that training will significantly drive the DCI opportunity starting with ZR/ZR+ optical products. Lastly, as more AI training platforms continue to extend to a larger and larger number of data centers, we don't rule out what used to be networking systems (Routers, ROADMs among others) used primarily by traditional telco companies, also seeing a strong ramp driven by a relatively nascent hyperscalers demand for long- range networking equipment systems for AI.

3) Rapid Margins Expansions...We expect LITE to continue to drive higher margins than expected by benefiting from the mix of OCS and chip-based products which are above corporate gross margins. Outside the multiple accretive products coming online over the next few quarters, we view the arrival of Michael Hurlston as an overall positive given his operator reputation. Following the Jun-Q results, investors seem to have approved off Michael Hurlston's pragmatic tone as he focuses on further unlocking profitability by 1) doubling down on strong growth/profitable businesses and streamlining modules projects 2) implementing a firm-wide new pricing strategy given LITE laser leadership and 3) improving LITE's manufacturing efficiency. We view positively the new management early
efforts and estimate that upon strong execution LITE may be on a path towards \(40\% +\) gross margin sooner than Street's expectations.
Figure 12. Citi's non-GAAP Gross Margin Estimates

1) Ramping competition...The company has toes on the water on the module front in both DCI AI transceivers where we expect LITE to be incumbent to companies such as COHR, Innolight, Cisco, Ciena among other. The intense competition at the module level comes with limited pricing power on top of challenges tied to lower margins initially. While we see the expansion to the module front as the natural next step for LITE, we also see challenges related to yields and ramps hampering margin early on.

2) Non-AI pieces remain stagnant: While it is clear LITE's datacom and DCI businesses are the key drivers of sales and the company's stock performance, it is important to note that currently over 50% of the business is tied to segments we expect to grow at LSD to MSD CAGR over the next 3 years.

IV- Company descriptionLumentum Holdings Inc. is a leader in optical and photonic market which delivers essential products to various end- markets including cloud, AI/ML, telecommunications, consumer, and industrial. LITE specifically focuses in two end- market focused reportable segments, Cloud & Networking and Industrial Tech.

End Market Dynamics:Lumentum's Cloud & Networking products include a portfolio of optical and photonic components, modules, and subsystems supplied to cloud and communications network operators and network equipment manufacturers. LITE products are integral parts of cloud data center infrastructure, including products for AI/ML and data center interconnect ("DCI") applications, and communications service provider networks, including products for access (local), metro (intracity), long- haul (city- to- city and worldwide), and submarine (undersea) network infrastructure. Lastly LITE's Cloud & Networking products also support network equipment manufacturers building enterprise network infrastructure. The primary demand drivers of this business is the rapid growth in cloud and network capacity required for expanding cloud computing and services, including for AI/ML, streaming video and video conferencing, gaming, wireless and mobile devices, and IoT.

Segment Dynamics: The segment represented \(86\%\) of sales in FY2025. We are modeling the segment to grow at \(32\%\) CAGR. The cloud and networking segment comprises telecom (which we estimate to be around \(59\%\) of the total segment sales and \(51\%\) of total sales) and datacom ( \(41\%\) of the networking segment and \(35\%\) ).
Figure 13.Key Networking Products
Source: Company Presentation
Figure 14. Rapidly Ramping AI TAM
Source: Company Presentation, LightCounting

LITE's second business is Industrial Tech where they provide products including.... solid- state lasers, kilowatt- class fiber lasers, diode lasers, ultrafast lasers, and gas lasers, which address applications in numerous end- markets. LITE's industrial lasers are incorporated into our customers' manufacturing machine tools used for the precision processing of materials in a range of industries including semiconductor device and microelectronics fabrication, electric vehicle and battery production, metal cutting and welding, and advanced manufacturing. Additionally, the company's product lasers are used for semiconductor inspection and life- science applications, as well as imaging and sensing systems for process feedback and control, quality assurance, and waste reduction. In the consumer end- market within the segment, Lumentum provides laser light sources that are integrated into 3D sensing cameras in mobile devices and other consumer electronics. In the automotive end- market, the company also provides lasers for LiDAR and other optical sensor devices, which are being used in advanced driver assistance systems ("ADAS") and in- cabin driver and occupant monitoring systems.

Segment Dynamics: The segment represented \(\sim 14\%\) of sales in FY2025, down from \(\sim 20\%\) amid a revenue decline of \(15\%\) in FY2025. As we look to outer years, we expect the segment to remain mostly flat as areas within the end- market such as Precision Manufacturing remained pressured by the challenging macro environment as evidenced by Manufacturing PMI which remains below 50, indicating a still shrinking manufacturing economy. We expect the segment to return to HSD growth \(2\%\) in FY2027E consistent with the LT market TAM precision material processing across diverse industries, including semiconductor and microelectronics fabrication, electric vehicle and battery production, metal cutting and welding, and advanced manufacturing. Adoption of their Industrial Tech products is driven by the need to advance semiconductor and microelectronics technology roadmaps and by Industry 4.0 and 5.0 trends that emphasize greater manufacturing precision, flexibility, and sustainability.

Michael Hurlston: President and Chief Executive Officer

Michael Hurlston: President and Chief Executive OfficerMichael Hurlston joined Lumentum as President and CEO in 2025. Prior to joining Lumentum, Hurlston served as President and Chief Executive Officer at Synaptics, Inc. Prior to Synaptics, Hurlston served as the Chief Executive Officer of Finisar Corporation, where he oversaw the company's agreement to be acquired by II- VI which ultimately became Coherent. Before joining Finisar, he served in a variety of senior leadership positions at Broadcom Limited and its predecessor corporation across the sales, marketing, and general management functions, including serving as its Senior Vice President and General Manager of the Mobile Connectivity Products/Wireless Communications and Connectivity Division.
Wajid Ali: Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

Wajid Ali: Executive Vice President and Chief Financial OfficerWajid Ali joined Lumentum in February 2019. Prior to Lumentum, Ali was the Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Synaptics. Before Synaptics, Ali was Vice President and Controller at Teledyne Technologies. Prior to Teledyne, he served as Chief Financial Officer at DALSA Corp., a semiconductor company that was acquired by Teledyne in 2011.
Kathy Ta: VP, IR & Corporate Marketing

Kathy Ta: VP, IR & Corporate MarketingKathy Ta joined Lumentum in Dec 2021. Prior to this role Kathy served for more than 8 years as the VP of Investor Relations and Corporate Responsibility for Maxim. Prior to Maxim, Kathy worked at Applied Materials in various roles with the latest being Chief Marketing Officer.

Wupen Yuen: President, Cloud and NetworkingWupen Yuen joined Lumentum in August 2022. Prior to this role, Yuen served as Senior Vice President and General Manager for both Lumentum's Telecom Transmission and Datacom business units. Yuen joined the company through Lumentum's acquisition of NeoPhotonics, where he had been Chief Product Officer since 2018, and Senior Vice President and General Manager since 2014. From 2005 to 2014, Yuen held numerous leadership roles within NeoPhotonics, including Senior Vice President of Product and Technology Development, Vice President of Product Development and Engineering, and Director of Business Development. From 2002 to 2004, Yuen served as Chief Technology Officer of Bandwidth9, a telecommunications tunable laser company.
We spoke with LITE's CEO, CFO and VP of IR and recap our key takeaways below.

CEO Assessment of the business after 6 months: Michael during our conversation was clear that demand is "unbelievable" as it continues to surprise on the upside. On the other end, Michael looks to improve LITE's execution. He described the company's execution to be choppy at times and given his operator reputation he has started a process to improve the operation of the company with an intense focus on finances. Management mentioned really focusing on margins by making sure the company is getting fair pricing from their customers. Michael focus will also be on improving the production of their internal factories where in areas such as cloud module execution has been choppy. Within those 6 months, while not fully fixed, management has nevertheless improved that aspect which helps supply get a little bit closer to demand which remains extremely strong.

Portfolio management: Management discussed earlier on, taking care of what can be called lower hanging fruits such as their metrology business which Lumentum's new management did not think was a good use of their investment. Similarly, the company had an X- ray business that they ended up shutting down. Even in cloud networking, the company discussed was really focusing the business and cutting some of the projects particularly in cloud modules to focus that business on just a handful of cloud module projects. This pivot has helped the business grow again last quarter with significant growth expected in 2026.

Margins: Cloud modules ramp is expected to be the biggest driver for margin over the next couple of quarters as LITE cloud transceivers margins are currently running below competition at this point. Combining continued growth on the remaining businesses and the new management operational improvements will ultimately lead to rapid margin expansion. Management also discussed that the \(\) amount of manufacturing overhead is on par with how much the company spends in OE, it is just hidden in COGRs. So as the company streamlines manufacturing, margin will benefit greatly from it. Finally, the other aspect that will help on the margin expansion is the introduction of new products. All new products going from CPO to OCS, to new EML and even CW products are above company level margins.

Path to \(\) 600M\(quarterly run - rate: Management expects to get there with minimal ramp in the cloud module\) (\ \(20M -\) 25M). Beyond the \(\) 600M\(run - rate, they expect the growth of the transceivers, the OCS and CPO products will bring them to the\) \ \(3B\) annual run- rate or \(\) 750M\(quarterly run - rate.

Capacity: Management started by saying that a lot of the decision around capacity for C2025 was made 2 years ago. At that time when the company was making capacity decisions in terms of both equipment and process node changes (from 3 to 4 inch), it was based on market data, supply chain checks and the feedback LITE was getting from their customers which they have strong visibility with. As they look to the next 2- 3 years, the company is making similar steps in order to figure out the right capacity investments to make now. Additionally, over the past quarters, the company has added more flexibility to its manufacturing. Beforehand, the company put most of their bets in internal manufacturing but with the new management coming on broad he has adopted a more flexible/hybrid manufacturing model (70% internal and 30% external with companies such as Fabrinet and other suppliers in Malaysia). This model allows the company to ramp or pull- down capacity as needed. In addition to outside manufacturers like Fabrinet, LITE has two module fabs in China and Thailand. In terms of the laser, LITE has 4 InP fabs with two driving the bulk of the activity. Two are in Japan allowing the company to modulate production depending on how much capacity is needed. The \(3^{\text{rd}}\) major fab is located in California, the fourth is in UK and is quite underutilized on purpose as it is used only in the case of excess demand.
Demand line...over the couple of quarters has gotten significantly steeper. Given this level of demand, LITE priority is really focusing the team on projects with large ROI.
EML for Al shares are \(\sim 50\%\) for 100G/lane, and they expect similar shares for 200G/lane EML once they start fully ramping.

EML vs CW: LITE is generally agnostic if CW comes faster. LITE nevertheless discussed that it has not seen EML demand diminish as the company is sold out until C2026. On CW, the company has for the first time introduced its CW lasers with the goal being to use it internally for their SiPho transceivers which at this point the company mainly outsources. The company aims to go fully internal in 1HC2026. Still on CW lasers the company also sells its products externally and saw marginal sales mix of CW lasers this quarter. The downside of a faster pivot to CW laser would be a less accretive margin profile than it is the case for EML, though both are above company- level margins. Additionally, management pointed out that that even after going internal in terms of manufacturing the margin profile for their SiPho transceivers would be in the 30- 35% range.

We model \(+2 / + 8\% / + 18\%\) FY2026E/FY2027E/FY2028E sales upside vs. Street and \(+3\% / + 10\% /15\%\) upside to Street's Non- GAAP EPS mainly on faster- than- expected margin expansion expectations.

LITE reported Jun- Q revs/non- GAAP (NG) EPS of \(480.7B / \$ 0.88\) and Street's (FactSet) \(470B / \$ 0.81\) . The company guided Sep- Q revenue/NG EPS of \(\) 525B/\$ 1.025 (at MP) vs. Street's \(\) 499.8/\$ 0.88.

LT GM: Non- GAAP gross margin: We expect LITE to continue driving higher margins than expected by benefitting from the mix of OCS and chip- based products. Our gross margin profile for both of those product lines that are going to drive that growth are above the corporate gross margins of the company. The ASP profile is substantially different between OCS and CPO products because the UHP laser products are chip products while OCS is more of a module- based product. So, the ASP delta is substantial, but both carry a combined gross margin profile that is above the company gross margin average. We model GM to rise 420 bps in FY2026 before reaching \(41.9\%\) and \(43.3\%\) in FY2027/FY2028.

At an operating margin front we expect the company to not only benefit from the sales growth leverage, but also its prior R&D investments. Given the company's 20 years plus experience in InP and the use of the latter across the majority of the company's products, LITE is able to benefit from the transversal aspect of its R&D investments. Talking to management Wajid Ali was clear that a lot of the R&D investments for EML was already made. Similarly for new products, such as OCS, are able to benefit from the foundation technology that that LITE got, both with MEMS and with WSS products. On an annual basis, we model non-GAAP operating margins to rise 9%, 4.1% and 2.5% in FY2026E, FY2027E and FY2028E to reach respectively 18.7%, 22.8% and 24.3%.

In terms of cash flow line items, we focus on LITE's FCF which we expect to turn positive in FY2027E as Capex on a fiscal year basis remain below \$400M while its cash flow from operations is multiplied by 4x from \$126M in FY2025 to \$592B in FY2027E we forecast.

VIII- ValuationWe value LITE at \$165 or 23x P/E applied to our FY2027E earnings power of \~\$7.16. Our 23x P/E multiple is at a 21% premium to 19x average P/E of AI optics peers. We model LITE to grow EPS at 58% CAGR in next three fiscal years vs. 40% AI optics peers. Therefore, on an earnings growth adjusted basis, we think a higher P/E multiple is justified.

indicator (News sentiment and concentration of sell- side analyst "Buy" ratings) and a lower ranking of its historical relative short interest (indicating more crowding on the long side). Over the past 3 months, the long- term price momentum of LITE increased from the \(91^{\text{st}}\) to the \(96^{\text{th}}\) percentile of the broad US stock universe. Our research shows stocks that have outperformed the most in the past 12 months tend to outperform again in the near term, hence high Price Momentum is often an attractive attribute for quant investors.

Further risk decomposition reveals that nearly three quarters of LITE's overall risk is idiosyncratic. It has a slight exposure to the macro factors, mostly attributed to credit risk and rising long- terms interest rates.

Despite LITE being up \(50\% +\) YTD, we continue to see further potential upside in the stock as we expect LITE to be more agnostic to the Al optics technology changes and module share dynamics. We expect the ECOC (Sept- 29 to Oct- 1) and OCP conference (Oct- 13 to Oct- 16) to be the next highly anticipated events for the company. We foresee LITE's 200G EML technology's adoption being a key topic at ECOC and believe the OCP's recently announced Optical Circuit Switching (OCS) project led by Lumentum could further shed light on OCS being a viable Al spine switch option vs. packet switches.

Lumentum Holdings Inc. is a leader in optical and photonic market which delivers essential products to various end- markets including cloud, AI/ML, telecommunications, consumer, and industrial. LITE specifically focuses in two end- market focused reportable segments, Cloud & Networking and Industrial Tech.
We are Buy- rated on LITE. We believe that the stock's multiple will benefit from the AI appeal while its fundamentals should expand on new management's strong execution and focus on profitability.

We value LITE at \(\) 165\(or\) 23x P/E\(applied to our FY2027E earnings power of\) \sim \$ 7.16. Our \(23x P/E\) multiple is at a \(21\%\) premium to 19x average P/E of AI optics peers. We model LITE to grow EPS at \(58\%\) CAGR in next three fiscal years vs. \(40\%\) AI optics peers. Therefore, on an earnings growth adjusted basis, we think a higher P/E multiple is justified.

Downside risks to the achievement of our target price include: 1) increased competition on AI leads to limited market share growth and limited revenue upside, 2) Frontloaded or slower- than- expected AI ramp affecting EML ramp, and 3) Slower than expected adoption of LITE CPO and OCS new products.

Upside risks to the achievement of our target price include: 1) gaining share in AI market through new products on the AI transceivers, CPO and OCS fronts 2) quicker and stronger adoption of AI workloads, and 3) faster- than- expected margin expansion.

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

Investment Ratings: Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus

the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of \(15\%\) or more or \(25\%\) or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "—" and "–" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re-establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short-term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management.
